subject: US MARKET WRAP 3 MAY 2019: NFP headline beat masks soft earnings growth/participation rate, stocks advance
content:
* SNAP SHOT: Equities up, dollar down, Treasuries up, crude flat.      

* REAR VIEW: NFP headline beats whilst average earnings misses, non-manufacturing ISM misses, Fed speakers emerge post FOMC       

* COMING UP: Monday: UK Holiday, Tuesday: RBA Monetary Policy Meeting, EIA Short-Term Energy Outlook, Australian Retail Sales and Trade Balance, German Industrial Orders and Output, Japan returns from Golden Week Holiday, Wednesday: RBNZ Monetary Policy Meeting, Brazilian Central Bank Monetary Policy Meeting, JMMC Meeting, China Trade Balance, Thursday: Norges Bank Monetary Policy Meeting, US International Trade, Friday: UK GDP Prelim, Canadian Jobs Data      

* MONDAY’S EARNINGS: TSN, SYY, PXD, FOX, OXY, AIG, KLAC        

* NFP: April payrolls rose by 263k, above the consensus of 190k, whilst unemployment fell to new cyclical lows of 3.6%, also below the consensus estimate of 3.8%. Pantheon Economics note uneven gains within the headline figure; the government component contributed 27k, some of which is likely hiring for the 2020 Census, and there was a 33k jump in construction, which is weather assisted and likely unsustainable. Conversely, the gains in manufacturing were meagre at 4k, while retail jobs declined by 12k. Private services were strong, up 202k, but Pantheon suggest that this could be catch up growth after a run of soft readings. “Most indicators of labour demand remain quite strong” the consultancy note, “but not strong enough to think private job gains at April’s pace can continue; we expect 175-to-200K over the next few months”. Regarding the participation rate, Pantheon note that the rise seen last Autumn has now been mostly reversed and at this rate, unemployment is set to dip below 3.5%. Moreover, the consultancy suggest that two calendar quirks may be attributable to the slightly weaker than anticipated average hourly earnings growth. “April was a relatively long month, with 22 working days, and the 15th - payday for people paid semi-monthly - fell after the survey week”, Pantheon say. “Both of these factors tend to depress AHE, and the April hit was slightly smaller than usual, suggesting that the underlying upward trend continues.” In sum, a strong report, but gains are unlikely to continue at this pace. Pantheon concludes that there are “no immediate policy implications, but its not hard to imagine that a run of reports like this would eventually prompt something of a rethink at the Fed.”      

* ISM Non-manufacturing PMI: The ISM’s non-manufacturing index fell to 55.5 from the 56.1 reading in March, below the consensus estimate of 57. Pantheon Economics note that the headline index has now reverted to the trend pace that had been in place prior to last year’s tax cuts, which drove consumer spending higher. As such, they expect no further decline. The consultancy then draws attention to the employment index, which dipped to 53.7 from 55.9, a number consistent with private sector pay growth of about 150k (in June). “That’s not bad” they note “but it serves to emphasize that April's 236K private payroll gain is very unlikely to signal a sustainable increase in the trend”.       

* FED: Fed speak was out in full force on Friday with multiple voting members expressing their views on the inflation situation in the US. The large slate was kicked off by Bullard in the US morning, expressing nerves over inflation and stating that a reset to expectations could be palatable. Evans then added to the post-FOMC Dollar rot, stating that a cut in rates may be necessary should the economy soften, but tempered this with the suggestion of hikes should inflation recover, but stated that downside risks appear the most prevalent. Whilst the neutral members Evans and Clarida echoes FOMC comments stating inflation concerns could be transitory, and the Fed can afford to be patient, Bullard eschewed his usual dovish tones stating he is open to a cut after summer should inflation remain light, which continued to pressure the DXY. Non-voter Mester also fell back to her usual tone, hawkishly stating that rates are appropriate where they are which rounded out the session on a largely neutral tone that fell largely in line with Fed guidance, sans Evans, who took the limelight suggesting cuts may be appropriate.      

*TRADE: As US-China trade talks wrapped up in Beijing, markets have been digging for signs of progress in key sticking issues as the two sides kept their cards close to their chest. The latest reports (from SCMP) noted that US believes that talks have been tempered by Beijing’s negotiators, who have suggested the tactic to “generate pressure” should not be taken “seriously”. However, during early US trade and ahead of further talks in Washington next week, VP Pence noted that President Trump is optimistic on a deal with China, albeit the issue of enforcement remains, whilst NEC Director Kudlow said the US will not soften its stance and there is room to add further tariffs against China, if necessary. Danske Bank believes that there is a 75% chance that markets will see a trade deal by the end of next week; “The two sides seem to have agreed on 95% of the content and, although a few difficult issues are left, we very much doubt that Trump will walk away from a deal.” Danske says. Analysts also note that if a deal is not reached in Washington next week, the resulting stock market decline would further pressure the two sides to get back to the negotiating table and get a deal done.      

* WTI (M9) FUTURES SETTLE USD 0.13 HIGHER AT USD 61.94; BRENT (N9) FUTURES SETTLE AT USD 70.85/BBL, UP USD 0.10. Oil prices were choppy during the European session where prices fluctuated within a USD 0.6/bbl range although the benchmarks were little changed following source reports stating that Saudi Arabia may raise output in May although the oil will be used for domestic power rather than a sign of succumbing to US pressure. May production is expected to be around 10mln BPD, below the OPEC+ output pact of 10.3mln BPD, despite the Saudi Energy Minister previously noting that end-May production will be “significantly below” 10mln BPD. Despite the recent rise in energy prices, WTI and Brent are poised to notch a second week of losses as US crude stockpiles overshadow Venezuela concerns, impacts from Iranian waiver expiry and OPEC-led production cuts. Next week will see the release of the EIA short-term energy outlook, albeit the OPEC and IAE Monthly Reports will be released in the following weeks.  

* SPX +1% at 2945, NDX +1.6% at 7846, DJI +0.8% at 26504. SECTORS: Communications -0.5%, Cons Discretionary +1.4%, Cons Staples +0.7%, Energy +0.8%, Financials +0.8%, Healthcare +0.8%, Industrials +1.2%, Materials +1%, Tech +1%, Telecoms +1.2%, Utilities +0.7%.      

* STOCKS SPECIFICS: JP Morgan Chase (JPM) opened higher after the investment bank signed a memorandum of understanding with Microsoft to develop its blockchain business, shrugging off news that the firm expect aggregate legal losses to total USD 1.4bln. Microsoft (MSFT) shares also moved higher. Amazon (AMZN) gained in the pre-market after Warren Buffet said that Berkshire Hathaway had been buying shares in the e-commerce co. Facebook (FB) moved higher on reports that the social media giant is in talks with MA V looks to build crypto payments system. American Express (AXP) opened higher on an upgrade at Morgan Stanley. Activision (ATVI) opened lower despite beating analyst expectations on both the top & bottom lines. Tesla (TSLA) moved higher on reports that the electric automaker were to boost their convertible notes offering to USD 1.6bln with CEO Musk now set to buy 25k shares. Arista Networks (ANET) fell substantially at the open, despite beating on the bottom line, as the firm downgraded Q2 guidance. EOG Resources (EOG) opened higher after the hydro-carbon exploration co reported earnings that beat on the bottom line and the firm raised its dividend. Fox Corp (FOX, FOXA) shares reversed early losses after the broadcaster announced plans to build a new media centre in Arizona. Monster (MNST) jumped at the open on better than expected top and bottom-line earnings. Herbalife Nutrition (HLF) opened lower after the firm missed analyst expectations on both the top and bottom lines and cut FY19 guidance. Cigna Corp’s (CI) stock price suffered on a downgraded at Goldman Sachs. Energy names, including Chevron (CVX), ExxonMobil (XOM) and ConocoPhillips (COP) rose as crude prices grinded higher.      

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) SETTLE 13 TICKS HIGHER AT 61.94. UST futures closed out the week lower on the day after a blow-out headline figure for NFPs, which saw some volatile action upon the release as average hourly earnings missed on their 0.3% and 3.3% forecast (0.2% and 3.2% respectively). Thus, 10yr yields didn’t sustain their initial bid and failed to break its 50DMA, with the bounce linked a block of 6k TYM9 supposedly lifted by a hedge fund. Thereafter, 7k USM9s were bought ahead of the ISM results, with the fixed income complex gaining speed afters some disappointing results. Fed speakers then took centre stage, with a largely neutral tone exhibited that fell in-line with FOMC guidance, ex-Evans, leading T-notes to trade within ranges heading into the close.    

* FX WRAP: It was a USD story today across dollar pairs; the greenback saw an initial kneejerk move higher on the strong headline NFP figure. However, the move was quickly faded; USD weakening sharply, as the focus of the market turned to the average earnings growth miss (0.2% M/M vs exp. 0.3% M/M) and the participation rate unexpectedly declining. Later in the session, USD came under further pressure from weak non-services PMI and notably dovish comments from Fed’s Evans. GBP saw no reaction to Markit Service PMI data, which came in as expected. However, it did outperform on the day vs its major G10 counterparts, GBPUSD breaking back above 1.3100, with NFP seemingly the catalyst amid a lack of other fundamental drivers. JPY strengthened vs USD but struggled to gain against most of its G10 counterparts, as stocks rose amid a rejuvenated appetite for risk. EUR was unresponsive as EZ inflation data came in above of expectations, but later caught a bid as USD weakened after NFP. AUD/NZD gained saw mild gains against USD, with apprehension regarding possible rate cuts in both countries limiting upside. The EM complex traded relatively benign; TRY was flat after benign CPI figures earlier in the day, which may ease concerns in the Eurasian country regarding inflationary pressures. Elsewhere, in Scandinavia, the NOK watchers will have derived little direction from unemployment data at the close of the week which came out in-line with expectations, and continues to stoke the flames of the outperforming Norwegian economy ahead of the Norges rate decision.

Weekly FX Wrap: watershed Fed, not so super BoE and more ‘just right’ US data
content:
DXY

The broad Dollar and index have lost their initial post-NFP vigour as relatively soft vs consensus wage components take the shine off a bumper headline payroll number, positive net 2 month back revisions and a near half century low jobless rate. However, the DXY remains well above weekly lows and closer to its best level set just after the labour data within a 97.144-98.112 range following a marked change in trend and sentiment on Wednesday. In sum, the FOMC trimmed the OIER by 5 bp as many expected, but stressed this was a technical move and Fed chair Powell struck a neutral tone in the post-meeting press conference. He downplayed recent soft inflation indicators more than once, as prices have been impacted by temporary factors and confounding the view for a more dovish shift in guidance (not to mention increased pressure from US President Trump and other Whitehouse officials) maintained that there is no compelling reason to change rates with the odds of the next move being a hike or cut pretty balanced.

NZD/CAD

On course to end Friday’s EU session at the top of the G10 table, and perhaps remarkably for the Kiwi quite near where it started the week even though markets are pretty evenly split over an RBNZ rate cut at the impending May policy meeting. Note, Nzd/Usd is now around 0.6645 vs 0.6658 at ‘open’ and vs a high of 0.6684 and low of 0.6604, with disappointing NZ jobs data for Q1 also in the mix. Meanwhile, the Loonie is on track to rack up net gains vs its US counterpart between 1.3489-3373 trading parameters despite the latest ‘Goldilocks’ US economic update (after last Friday’s flash Q1 GDP release that showed stellar growth without PCE price pressure) and a steep retreat in crude prices.

GBP/NOK 

The next best majors on the final day of the week, but the Pound and Norwegian Krona have enjoyed or endured markedly mixed fortunes over the week overall. Indeed, Cable is back towards the top of its 1.3100-1.2900 band, partly on the aforementioned loss of Greenback momentum, but also in wake of reports that Brexit talks between the Government and opposition Labour Party have been a bit more productive. Note, the UK construction and services PMIs regained 50+ status, albeit just vs a slowdown in manufacturing after Brexit stockpiling, but all 3 surveys had little impact on Sterling. Similarly, BoE super Thursday did not really live up to its billing, although there was some reaction as the MPC maintained unanimity on rates as opposed to some calls for a hawkish dissenter, or even 2, and reiterated guidance for gradual and limited tightening. Moreover, QIR estimates were based on a slightly lower end of forecast horizon rate (1% vs 1.1% in February), but Governor Carney reiterated that markets are not factoring in enough tightening. Back to the Pound, it is also outpacing the Euro with the cross down around 0.8550 vs just over 0.8650 at one stage and circa 0.8625 at the start of the week. In contrast, the sharp retracement in oil noted above and a softer Norwegian manufacturing PMI have contributed to a spike in Eur/Nok to 9.8135 from 9.6595, with the SEK also suffering as the Swedish headline declined to 50.9 from 52.8, and that cross has rallied from 10.5957 to 10.7130 before drifting back.

AUD/EUR/JPY/CHF

The Aussie has pared some losses from a minor new 2019 low vs its US peer (0.6985), but remains tethered to 0.7000 vs 0.7070 at best and not far from 1.0550 lows against its Kiwi rival vs 1.0600+ at the other extreme ahead of next week’s RBA meeting that is also seen tight in terms of an ease. Conversely, the single currency has rebounded from worst levels vs the Dollar within a 1.1265-1.1133 range after firmer than expected Eurozone inflation data and encouraging manufacturing PMIs with the notable exception of a slightly more contractionary German print. Similarly, the Yen has appreciated vs the Usd between 111.90-03 bounds and in the absence of Japanese participants during the extended Golden Week break, while the Franc is hovering around the middle of its 1.0125-1.0215 range in wake of a sub-50 Swiss manufacturing PMI, more negative SECO consumer sentiment and benign Swiss CPI.

EM 

Another roller-coaster ride for the Lira, but yet more losses towards the 6.0000 level vs the Dollar as sub-forecast Turkish inflation failed to stop the rot and only raised speculation that the CBRT may shy even further away from tightening.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 3rd May 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European indices on the front foot [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.3%], but bonds backpedaling pre-NFP
  • USD remains firm with the DXY just below the 98.0 level ahead of NFP
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US Jobs Reports, US ISM Non-Manufacturing, Fed's Evans, Clarida, Williams & Bowman
  • Earnings: Berkshire Hathaway, American Tower

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mixed with the region cautious ahead of the looming US NFP data and after losses on Wall St where the fallout from the FOMC disappointment persisted and the energy sector underperformed on weaker oil prices. ASX 200 (U/C) swung between gains and losses with notable weakness seen in energy names after WTI crude declined by more than 3% and with financials subdued after Macquarie’s full-year results which improved from the prior year although it flagged a decline for FY20. KOSPI (-0.7%) and Hang Seng (+0.4%%) were negative with South Korea heavily focused on earnings and with risk appetite in Hong Kong sapped by poor GDP data which showed its economy grew at the slowest pace in nearly a decade. However, the Hang Seng is well off intraday lows as trade related news provided a glimmer of optimism with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang to travel to the US on Tuesday and is expected to close the trade deal next week, while US Commerce Secretary Ross suggested they are in the end-game of trade negotiations. As a reminder, mainland China and Japan remained closed for holidays.

 

US

US President Trump suggested no more costly and time-consuming investigations, while he called on parties to work together on immigration, infrastructure and much lower drug prices. (Twitter)

UK/EU

Latest UK local council elections results show Labour Party councillors dropped by 53 councillors to 601 and Conservative party councillors dropped by 117 to 512 in England. (BBC) Instead, voters turned to alternative parties which saw a significant swell in support for the Liberal Democrats, the Greens and independent candidates. (Sky News)

UK PM May spokesman states that the PM expects Brexit talks to resume with Labour after the weekend. (Newswires)

BoE's Broadbent says one quarter point rise in interest rates would not be particularly dramatic, reaffirms guidance around a limited and gradual tightening. (Newswires)

ECB's Weidmann says that inspite of Q1 there is still no overall improvement in the economy, Germany likely posted solid Q1 growth but this was assisted by one-off factors; adds that 0.5% growth in Germany this year is plausible. (Newswires)

EU's Juncker said ECB's Weidmann is a suitable candidate for the ECB president position. (Handelsblatt)

EU leaders are scheduling a meeting on the 28th May following the EU parliament elections., according to Officials. (Newswires)

UK Markit/CIPS Services PMI (Apr) 50.4 vs. Exp. 50.5 (Prev. 48.9). (Newswires)

EU HICP-X F&E Flash YY (Apr) 1.3% vs. Exp. 1.1% (Prev. 1.0%)

- EU HICP-X F, E, A & T Flash YY (Apr) 1.2% vs. Exp. 1.00% (Prev. 0.80%)

- EU HICP Flash YY (Apr) 1.7% vs. Exp. 1.6% (Prev. 1.4%)

 

EQUITIES

Major European indices have been gradually grinding higher throughout the session [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.3%], diverging from the cautious trade seen overnight where sentiment was somewhat deterred by the upcoming US jobs report and mixed US-China trade reports. There is no real standout European bourse this morning with gains relatively broad based; although, the SMI (+0.2%) while positive is underperforming its peers, with the index weighed on by Swiss Re (-2.6%) after the Co. posted a miss on Q1 net. In a similar fashion sectors are predominantly in the green with the exception of the Technology sector which is weighed on by heavyweight Sap (-0.4%) in the red following on from reports yesterday that up to 50k companies which are using the Co’s software are at risk of a security breach; the Co. state that guidance on resolving these issues was published in both 2009 and 2013. Other notable movers this morning include banking giant HSBC (+2.4%) who are firmer post-earnings where they beat on both Q1 revenue and pre-tax profit. Separately, but also boosted by earnings are Adidas (+6.1%) with the Co. also topping the Dax (+0.3%) after confirming FY guidance and reporting strong net income & operating figures. Elsewhere, and at the other end of the Stoxx 600 are Intu Properties (-6.4%), after stating that they see FY19 LFL retail income falling by 4-6% and forecast the remainder of the year as being challenging.

Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.B) has invested in Amazon (AMZN) for the first time, Warren Buffet stated in an interview that he himself had not made the decision but one of his deputies made the decision to purchase the stake. (FT)

Boeing (BA) have limited the role of their pilots in their 737 MAX flight-control system development, as according to sources. (WSJ)

 

FX

USD - The Greenback remains on a firmer footing ahead of the monthly BLS jobs report, and the index has just notched a new post-FOMC peak at 97.971 amidst expectations that payrolls will post another solid gain, with average earnings forecast to tick up in m/m and y/y terms. The DXY has eclipsed Fib resistance at 97.881 in the process and is now eyeing another retracement level just above 98.000 at 98.059.

CHF/EUR/GBP/JPY/AUD - All weaker, albeit marginally vs the Usd, with the Franc straddling 1.0200 after a further deterioration in Swiss consumer sentiment and in line/steady y/y CPI, but still well shy of the SNB’s 2% target. Meanwhile, the single currency is grinding down further having relinquished the 1.1200 handle on Thursday with Fibs marking out support and resistance at 1.1147 and 1.1186 respectively, and hefty option expiry interest also likely to influence trade/direction ahead of NFP if not the NY cut. Note, firmer than forecast Eurozone inflation has been largely shrugged off given national numbers indicating an upside bias vs consensus. Similarly, Cable failed to glean and positive momentum from confirmation that the UK services sector joined its construction counterpart back into expansion from contraction, with the pair having dipped below the 1.3000 level to circa 1.2990 (just shy of the 100DMA at 1.2983) while Usd/Jpy is pivoting 111.50 and the 30 DMA (111.47) in advance of the aforementioned US labour data and a 111.70 Fib. Last, but by no means least, the Aussie is trying to keep sight of the psychological 0.7000 mark following extended losses to a fractional 2019 low (0.6985) where decent expiry interest (877 mn) resides, but still wary about a potential RBA rate cut next week.

CAD/NZD - Marginal G10 outperformers, or at least holding their own as the Loonie meanders between 1.3458-75 and Kiwi hovers above 0.6600, albeit also conscious that the RBNZ could ease policy at the May meet.

EM - The Lira remains in the spotlight and under pressure in wake of weaker than anticipated Turkish CPI on perceived less hawkish CBRT policy implications, with Usd/Try at the upper end of 5.5800-9595 trading parameters.

Australian Building Approvals (Mar) M/M -15.5% vs. Exp. -14.0% (Prev. 19.1%). (Newswires) Australian Building Approvals (Mar) Y/Y -27.3% vs. Exp. -25.1% (Prev. -12.5%)

FIXED INCOME

Bunds and Gilts have regrouped after succumbing to more selling pressure and extending respective intraday lows to 164.84 and 126.95, -40 and -32 ticks on the day. Coincidentally, the deeper Eurex trough aligned exactly with this week’s previous base (April 30), while the Liffe nadir was just a tick short of 126.94, also posted on Tuesday, and the lack of follow-through to the downside and/or stop tripping appears to have encouraged jobbers and enticed buyers. Meanwhile, US Treasuries are nestling near the bottom of relative narrow overnight session ranges into NFP, non-manufacturing PMI and ISM releases and a whole host of Fed speakers following Wednesday’s somewhat surprise more hawkish/less dovish FOMC, and Powell in particular.

COMMODITIES

Brent (-0.5%) and WTI (-0.2%) prices are subdued this morning, as the general uptick in risk appetite this morning has not been able to outweigh the bearish pressure from the stronger dollar. WTI prices are still relatively secure above the USD 61/bbl level, currently trading around the USD 61.40 figure; however, the session lows for Brent did briefly breach the USD 70/bbl level. UBS note that of central concern for oil on the upside are the recent reports that US-China trade talks may have reached an impasse, ahead of next week’s negotiations in Washington. News flow this morning includes sources commenting that Saudi Arabia’s production may increase in June but will still be below the 10.3mln BPD quota under the OPEC+ agreement. For reference, surveys indicate that Saudi Arabia’s output as of April 30th is 9.85mln BPD.

Gold (U/C) is relatively lacklustre this morning with the yellow metal torn between the firmer dollar, mixed US-China trade reports and the general improvement in risk sentiment; as such the metal is left pivoting the USD 1270/oz level. Elsewhere, copper is still suffering from the absence of China, although industrial metals in general have strengthened somewhat with some attributing this to recent comments from Tesla, stating that they foresee shortages of minerals which are used in electric vehicles.

US is considering sanctioning businesses involved in Iran petrochemical trade and is stepping up efforts to sever Iran's non-USD trade, while it is also looking at sanctioning banks doing business with Iran. In other news, Iran Oil Minister Zanganeh said they will not remain silent if other OPEC members threaten its interests and commented that an OPEC collapse is likely. (Newswires/WSJ)

Venezuela opposition lawmaker Lopez says it is clear there are more military movements to come. (Newswires)

LA County Fire Department says it is responding to a fire at the Phillips 66 Carson California refinery. (Newswires)

Hungary, Poland and the Czech Republic are to provide around 8mln bbls of crude from their strategic stockpiles amid the Druzhba pipeline shutdown, according to sources. (Newswires)

Saudi Arabia's oil production may increase in June, but is set to remain within the OPEC+ quota., according to sources. (Newswires)

EM - The Lira remains in the spotlight and under pressure in wake of weaker than anticipated Turkish CPI on perceived less hawkish CBRT policy implications, with Usd/Try at the upper end of 5.5800-9595 trading parameters.

FIXED INCOME

Bunds and Gilts have regrouped after succumbing to more selling pressure and extending respective intraday lows to 164.84 and 126.95, -40 and -32 ticks on the day. Coincidentally, the deeper Eurex trough aligned exactly with this week’s previous base (April 30), while the Liffe nadir was just a tick short of 126.94, also posted on Tuesday, and the lack of follow-through to the downside and/or stop tripping appears to have encouraged jobbers and enticed buyers. Meanwhile, US Treasuries are nestling near the bottom of relative narrow overnight session ranges into NFP, non-manufacturing PMI and ISM releases and a whole host of Fed speakers following Wednesday’s somewhat surprise more hawkish/less dovish FOMC, and Powell in particular.

COMMODITIES

Brent (-0.5%) and WTI (-0.2%) prices are subdued this morning, as the general uptick in risk appetite this morning has not been able to outweigh the bearish pressure from the stronger dollar. WTI prices are still relatively secure above the USD 61/bbl level, currently trading around the USD 61.40 figure; however, the session lows for Brent did briefly breach the USD 70/bbl level. UBS note that of central concern for oil on the upside are the recent reports that US-China trade talks may have reached an impasse, ahead of next week’s negotiations in Washington. News flow this morning includes sources commenting that Saudi Arabia’s production may increase in June but will still be below the 10.3mln BPD quota under the OPEC+ agreement. For reference, surveys indicate that Saudi Arabia’s output as of April 30th is 9.85mln BPD.

Gold (U/C) is relatively lacklustre this morning with the yellow metal torn between the firmer dollar, mixed US-China trade reports and the general improvement in risk sentiment; as such the metal is left pivoting the USD 1270/oz level. Elsewhere, copper is still suffering from the absence of China, although industrial metals in general have strengthened somewhat with some attributing this to recent comments from Tesla, stating that they foresee shortages of minerals which are used in electric vehicles.

subject: FX Morning Colour: DXY nudging 98.000 ahead of NFP
content:
USD

The Greenback remains on a firmer footing ahead of the monthly BLS jobs report, and the index has just notched a new post-FOMC peak at 97.971 amidst expectations that payrolls will post another solid gain, with average earnings forecast to tick up in m/m and y/y terms. The DXY has eclipsed Fib resistance at 97.881 in the process and is now eyeing another retracement level just above 98.000 at 98.059.

CHF/EUR/GBP/JPY/AUD

All weaker, albeit marginally vs the Usd, with the Franc straddling 1.0200 after a further deterioration in Swiss consumer sentiment and in line/steady y/y CPI, but still well shy of the SNB’s 2% target. Meanwhile, the single currency is grinding down further having relinquished the 1.1200 handle on Thursday with Fibs marking out support and resistance at 1.1147 and 1.1186 respectively, and hefty option expiry interest also likely to influence trade/direction ahead of NFP if not the NY cut. Note, firmer than forecast Eurozone inflation has been largely shrugged off given national numbers indicating an upside bias vs consensus. Similarly, Cable failed to glean and positive momentum from confirmation that the UK services sector joined its construction counterpart back into expansion from contraction as it retreats closer towards 1.3000, while Usd/Jpy is pivoting 111.50 and the 30 DMA (111.47) in advance of the aforementioned US labour data and a 111.70 Fib. content: Gilts have retreated further from fleeting post-BoE highs in line with the bearish tone in Bunds that is now also seeping through to US Treasuries as the German benchmark extends losses through technical support and under Thursday’s 164.97 Eurex low to 164.88. The 10 year UK debt future is just holding within a 126.99-127.22 range compared to yesterday’s 127.27 Liffe settlement, while Short Sterling contracts are somewhat mixed and straddling parity with the longer end marginally underperforming. Looking ahead, April’s services PMI forms the domestic highlight ahead of the US labour report and after comments from MPC’s Broadbent offered little new in terms of policy insight (repeated gradual and limited tightening mantra, with a 25 bp/year pace for some additional guidance). Back to Liffe, but on the issuance front the DMO has chosen leads for forthcoming long end supply that is due in the week commencing May 13 and will be in the 2054-2061 bucket (precise maturity to be decided).

3rd May 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were mixed with the region cautious ahead of the looming US NFP data and after losses on Wall St where the fallout from the FOMC disappointment persisted and the energy sector underperformed on weaker oil prices. ASX 200 (+0.1%) swung between gains and losses with notable weakness seen in energy names after WTI crude declined by more than 3% and with financials subdued after Macquarie’s full-year results which improved from the prior year although it flagged a decline for FY20. KOSPI (-0.7%) and Hang Seng (-0.1%) were negative with South Korea heavily focused on earnings and with risk appetite in Hong Kong sapped by poor GDP data which showed its economy grew at the slowest pace in nearly a decade. However, the Hang Seng is well off intraday lows as trade related news provided a glimmer of optimism with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang to travel to the US on Tuesday and is expected to close the trade deal next week, while US Commerce Secretary Ross suggested they are in the end-game of trade negotiations. RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 3rd May 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian equity markets were mixed with the region cautious ahead of the looming US NFP data and after losses on Wall St
  • A report suggested that US and China trade talks may have hit an impasse. However, comments from US Commerce Secretary Ross suggested the two nations are in the end-game of negotiations
  • Latest UK local council election results show Labour Party councillors dropped by 53 to 601 and Conservative party councillors dropped by 117 to 512 in England
  • Looking ahead, highlights include UK Services PMI, EZ CPI (Flash), US Jobs Reports, US ISM Non-Manufacturing, Fed's Evans, Clarida, Williams & Bowman, BoE's Broadbent
  • Earnings: Berkshire Hathaway, American Tower, Adidas, BASF, Fiat, Societe Generale, HSBC

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mixed with the region cautious ahead of the looming US NFP data and after losses on Wall St where the fallout from the FOMC disappointment persisted and the energy sector underperformed on weaker oil prices. ASX 200 (+0.1%) swung between gains and losses with notable weakness seen in energy names after WTI crude declined by more than 3% and with financials subdued after Macquarie’s full-year results which improved from the prior year although it flagged a decline for FY20. KOSPI (-0.7%) and Hang Seng (-0.1%) were negative with South Korea heavily focused on earnings and with risk appetite in Hong Kong sapped by poor GDP data which showed its economy grew at the slowest pace in nearly a decade. However, the Hang Seng is well off intraday lows as trade related news provided a glimmer of optimism with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang to travel to the US on Tuesday and is expected to close the trade deal next week, while US Commerce Secretary Ross suggested they are in the end-game of trade negotiations. As a reminder, mainland China and Japan remained closed for holidays.

 

A report suggested that US and China trade talks may have hit an impasse as this week’s negotiations had fewer details about specific discussions and results, although some analysts suggested that fewer details mean they are closer to a deal and the report also noted that both sides voiced commitment to the talks. (Global Times/PTI) However, later comments from US Commerce Secretary Ross suggested the two nations are in the end-game of trade negotiations and both sides continue to make progress on a range of issues. Furthermore, Ross said the US is not likely to get the desired commitments from China to cut back on industrial subsidies and expects US govt to continue to use Section 301 despite potential US-China trade deal (Newswires)

UK/EU

Latest UK local council elections results show Labour Party councillors dropped by 53 councillors to 601 and Conservative party councillors dropped by 117 to 512 in England. (BBC) Instead, voters turned to alternative parties which saw a significant swell in support for the Liberal Democrats, the Greens and independent candidates. (Sky News)

ECB's Rehn commented that the ECB shouldn't jump the gun after the first sign of stronger data. (Newswires)

EU's Juncker said ECB's Weidmann is a suitable candidate for the ECB president position. (Handelsblatt)

FX

 

FX markets were relatively quiet amid continued holiday closures and with participants sidelined ahead of the key US jobs data. As such, the DXY was rangebound around the 97.50 level as it held on to post-FOMC gains and after better than expected Factory Orders added to the support for the currency, while its major counterparts were subdued in which EUR/USD languished below 1.1200. GBP/USD consolidated overnight post-BoE, while elections results overnight showed both Tories and Labour suffered losses but failed to impact the currency given that the elections were at the local council level. Elsewhere, antipodeans were lacklustre amid softer commodity prices and ahead of next week’s central bank meetings which are seen as ‘live’ for potential rate cuts from both the RBA and RBNZ, while weaker than expected Building Approvals also briefly weighed on AUD/USD.

Australian Building Approvals (Mar) M/M -15.5% vs. Exp. -14.0% (Prev. 19.1%). (Newswires) Australian Building Approvals (Mar) Y/Y -27.3% vs. Exp. -25.1% (Prev. -12.5%)

COMMODITIES 

Commodities were lacklustre overnight with WTI crude despondent after the prior day’s drop of over 3% and brief test of the USD 61.00/bbl level to the downside where it eventually found support. The weakness in prices was attributed to a firmer greenback and the subdued risk appetite in the aftermath of the FOMC, while some also suggested a deepening of the correction to this year’s rally and Citi cited Russia production keeping output levels above the OPEC+ target. Elsewhere, gold was restrained as the greenback held on to its gains and participants tentative ahead of the key US jobs data, while copper’s attempts to nurse losses were kept feeble by the absence of Chinese participants and subdued price action across the complex.

US is considering sanctioning businesses involved in Iran petrochemical trade and is stepping up efforts to sever Iran's non-USD trade, while it is also looking at sanctioning banks doing business with Iran. In other news, Iran Oil Minister Zanganeh said they will not remain silent if other OPEC members threaten its interests and commented that an OPEC collapse is likely. (Newswires/WSJ)

Venezuela opposition lawmaker Lopez says it is clear there are more military movements to come. (Newswires)

Valero Memphis, Tennessee refinery was knocked out of production due to a pipeline malfunction, while there were also reports of a fire at the Phillips 66 Carson, California refinery. (Newswires)

US

US Treasuries once again had a slow start to the session in Asia-Pac, but as the Europeans returned from holiday, some selling was noted after poor German data. Henceforth the selling stalled after stellar US factory orders (MM 1.9% vs. prev. -0.3% & exp. 1.6%) that detracted from some weekly claims ticking up, and durable goods revisions. Thereafter, while the day’s headline grabber came from source reports suggesting an impasse on US-Sino trade-talks, little follow through was seen in USTs, which diverged on Thursday from a declining stock space. As such the block flattener noted following the US data (12k+ in TYM9 vs. 3k+ Ultra Longs) set the tone for the day with 10yr yield approaching its 50DMA towards the close and T-note futures settled -13 ticks at 123-13+.

US President Trump suggested no more costly and time-consuming investigations, while he called on parties to work together on immigration, infrastructure and much lower drug prices. (Twitter)

US President Trump announced that Fed Nominee Stephen Moore has withdrawn from nomination process. (Newswires)

subject: ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia trades cautious following the continued post-FOMC fallout in US and amid cautiousness ahead of US NFPs
content:
Asia equity markets are lower with sentiment in the region dampened after the losses on Wall St in a continuation of the fallout from the FOMC disappointment and where the energy sector underperformed on weaker oil prices, while looming US NFP jobs data further adds to the cautiousness. ASX 200 (+0.2%) is indecisive with notable weakness seen in energy names after WTI crude declined by more than 3% and with financials subdued after Macquarie’s full-year results which improved from the prior year but flagged a decline for FY20. KOSPI (-0.6%) and Hang Seng (-0.3%) are negative with South Korea heavily focused on earnings and with risk appetite in Hong Kong sapped by poor GDP data which showed its economy grew at the slowest pace in nearly a decade. Conversely, trade related news continues to provide a glimmer of optimism with Chinese Foreign Minister Wang to travel to the US and is expected to close the trade deal next week, while US Commerce Secretary Ross suggested they are in the end-game of trade negotiations although the Asia-Pac region has failed to benefit with mainland China and Japan participants absent from the market again.

FX markets are relatively quiet amid continued holiday closures and with participants sidelined ahead of the key US jobs data. As such, the DXY is rangebound around the 97.50 level as it holds on to post-FOMC gains and with better than expected Factory Orders adding to the support for the currency, while its major counterparts are subdued with EUR/USD languishing below 1.1200. GBP/USD consolidates overnight after the recent BoE-triggered indecision as the MPC continued to suggest the appropriateness of tighter policy if the economy develops broadly in line with its Inflation Report projections. Elsewhere, antipodeans are lacklustre amid softer commodity prices and ahead of next week’s central bank meetings which are seen as ‘live’ for potential rate cuts from both the RBA and RBNZ, while weaker than expected Building Approvals also briefly weighed on AUD/USD.
